awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cosmics Leaving OUtdoor Droplets (CLOUD) Consortium Membership
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the continued membership in the CLOUD consortium at CERN, by Carnegie-Mellon University and the California Institute of Technology, and provides new membership for the University of Colorado at Boulder.  The CLOUD (Cosmics Leaving OUtdoor Droplets) experimental facility is likely the world's most sophisticated experiment addressing atmospheric new-particle formation.  It was constructed to measure new particle formation under highly controlled, ultra-clean conditions.

CLOUD is an international member-funded consortium supporting the maintenance and operation of the experiment.  Members raise research funding from their national agencies to participate. Experiments are conducted at CERN during 1-2 carefully planned campaigns per year, each lasting 8-10 weeks. These campaigns are planned, and data are assessed, during two major week-long consortium meetings each year, while more focused, intensive data analysis is carried out at all times by individuals, but also in several focused team meetings scheduled and hosted on an ad-hoc basis during the course of each year as analysis and interpretation require. Virtual team meetings via skype and other media are ongoing and continuous.

In addition to providing the required consortium fee, this project will support shipping and travel to CLOUD experimental campaigns and associated consortium meetings and data workshops. The doctoral and postdoctoral students associated with the project will be integrated into an international collaborative network of students and senior researchers who are among the most highly regarded in aerosol science and atmospheric chemistry. They will receive invaluable training in the conduct of international collaborative research.

The subject of the CLOUD experiments is of high national and international interest. Aerosol-cloud interactions are among the largest sources of uncertainty in the understanding of climate forcing and climate sensitivity. CLOUD experiments confirm that ions can stabilize nucleating clusters, and that, for otherwise weakly bound clusters (such as ammonia sulfuric acid, organics with sulfuric acid, and pure organics), ions can enhance nucleation rates by factors of 3-100 depending on conditions.  During the period of this project, three campaigns, CLOUD-13, CLOUD-14, and CLOUD-15, are planned.   The campaigns will focus on the following broad topics: the role of organic oxidation chemistry in new-particle formation and growth; new-particle formation in urban areas; new-particle formation in the marine atmosphere; and the role, if any, of charge in cloud-droplet formation and ice-crystal nucleation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University participated in the Cosmics Leaving OUtdoor Droplets (CLOUD) collaboration at CERN, conducting experiments and developing models to simulate the chemistry and physics of particle formation and growth under a wide range of conditions encountered in the atmosphere. Nucleation and growth is responsible for well over half of all particles that serve as Cloud Condensation Nuclei (CCN), and changes to CCN number are a leading uncertainty in our understanding of climate change. Predicting CCN changes in a decarbonizing world is an equally major uncertainty to unerstanding future climate and informing mitigation policies.

Findings from experiments led by CMU established that below 0 C, nitric acid can play a key role in atmospheric new-particle formation and growth. Under wintertime megacity conditions, ammonium nitrate condensation can accelerate nucleated particle growth by 100 fold for short bursts, carrying particles through the "valey of death" between 2 and 5 nm. In upper tropospheric conditions, nucleation involving a mix of nitric and sulfuric acid as well as ammonia carried in convective systems and evolved from detrained ice crystals may dominate particle formation and total particle number in the tropical upper troposphere, at least within the extensive influence of the Asian Monsoon.

Organic material with volatility measured by the CMU instrumentation confirms volatility parameterizations we have been using for several years but also establishes that very different mechanisms for biogenic (terpene) and anthropogenic (aromatic) oxidation result in different functional group distributions and thus different volatility parameterizations (both of which we had derived theoretically but which are now confirmed experimentally). These are crucial to understanding the role of organic oxidation products in particle formation and especially growth, which is especially important in the lower atmosphere over continents as well as in parts of the upper troposphere such as the Amazon.

The same observations confirm an emerging understanding of key short-lived intermediate organic radicals, known as peroxy radicals. These sit at the center of tropospheric chemistry, and in addition to reacting with other species can react with themselves in the presence of oxygen - a process known as autoxidation - and form exotic and very low volatility products. The extent of peroxy radical autoxidation depends strongly on temperature and largely counteracts the general increase in volatiliyt expected with increasing temperature. These thermal desorption measurements also confirm the presence of covalently bound "dimers" from peroxy radical association.

CLOUD also found that marine particle formation involving iodic and iodous acids as well as methane sulfonic acid establish that a rich mixture of non sulfuric acid nucleating inorganic species may dominate particle formation in the marine atmosphere. Overall the research addressed both cleean and polluted conditions over the continents as well as evolving marine conditions and finally the processes of the upper troposphere.

In addition to the transformative scientific findings, the research formed a key part of the doctoral dissertations of six Carnegie Mellon University doctoral students and one postdoctoral researcher.
